intro: Ophiocaulon cissampeloides, commonly known as the Mexican rock nettle, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and is often found in dry, open habitats. Its flowers are small and clustered, producing distinctive, five-lobed petals. Ophiocaulon cissampeloides is known for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its unique foliage.
